background: Frozen ground is one of the six major components in the cryosphere (Harris et al. 2018) and a unique long-term climate change and geological evolution product (Henry and Smith 2001; Jin et al. 2011). Recently, the permafrost on the Tibetan Plateau (TP) considerably degraded in the context of climate warming and increasing anthropogenic activities (Zhao et al. 2004; Ran et al. 2018; Luo et al. 2018a; Qin et al. 2017; Hu et al. 2019), which poses significant influences on the surface energy balance, ecosystem diversity, biogeochemical cycles, hydrology cycles, and greening gas emissions (Frauenfeld et al. 2004; Guo et al. 2011; Zhang et al. 2018; Peng et al. 2019; Luo et al. 2018c, 2020; Zhou et al. 2020). Soil freeze depth (SFD) is one of the most important parameters and is an essential indicator of climate change in the cryosphere (Peng et al. 2017), which is vital to both seasonally frozen ground and permafrost. Under climate warming (Ahmed et al. 2020), SFD decreases when the near-surface frozen ground begins to thaw (Frauenfeld et al. 2004; Peng et al. 2017, 2020). Long-term observations of permafrost and SFD are inadequate on the TP, with some exceptions along the Qinghai-Tibet engineering corridor (Wu and Zhang 2008, 2010) and northeastern TP (Luo et al. 2018a, b), at which these observations were aimed at monitoring the stability of engineering projects and the response of eco-environment to climate change (Wu et al. 2019; Zhou et al. 2016).
research objective: In this study, we first calculated the maximum SFD from 1901 to 2016 in the UBRB based on the UEA-CRU and the UDEL and then analyzed the relationship between maximum SFD and the thermal regime of frozen ground. We aimed at (1) obtaining the spatial and temporal variations of SFD in the UBRB, (2) quantifying climate change and its influence on SFD change over the UBRB, and (3) comparing the results of maximum SFD and frozen ground changes simulated with two respective datasets.
challenges: Moreover, the accuracies of calculating may be deviated by the soil edaphic parameter. Calculating accuracy may be reduced by the ignorance or simple treatments of E value.
methods: In this study, we adopted the Stefan equation to simulate the regional maximum SFD over the UBRB from 1901 to 2016 with monthly near-surface air temperatures from the University of East Anglia Climatic Research Unit (UEA-CRU) and the University of Delaware (UDEL). Observations from 11 national meteorological stations over the UBRB and 6 nearby were used to calibrate relevant parameters and evaluate the simulations. We used the Stefan equation to calculate the annual maximum SFD at all national meteorological stations and each grid point with the UEA-CRU and the UDEL.
dataset: The UEA-CRU TS 4.03 with a spatial resolution of half-degree is collected from the Climatic Research Unit (CRU) of the University of East Anglia. Another monthly air temperature dataset throughout 1900–2017 was extracted from the reanalysis products released by the University of Delaware (UDEL). Daily soil freeze depth was directly measured by thaw tubes at the national meteorological stations across China. Daily air and ground surface temperatures were collected from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA). In total, 11 meteorological stations in the UBRB and 6 additional meteorological stations in the adjacent region were selected.
findings: Approximately 97.94% and 96.21% of the UBRB were covered with the frozen ground as simulated with the UEA-CRU and the UDEL, respectively. The maximum SFD calculated with the UEA-CRU and the UDEL decreased respectively by about 0.31 m and 0.15 m over the past 116 years. Simulations with both datasets demonstrated that no significant changes of SFD occurred in the past four 30-year periods (i.e., 1901–1930, 1931–1960, 1961–1990, and 1991–2016), while the maximum SFD calculated with the UEA-CRU was smaller than that with the UDEL. All of these features demonstrated a warming trend of frozen ground from 1901 to 2016 in the UBRB.

Definition.Question: What are the potential challenges in calculating soil freeze depth using temperature datasets?
Definition.Answer: Potential challenges in calculating soil freeze depth may include deviations in accuracy due to the soil edaphic parameter and reductions in calculating accuracy caused by the ignorance or oversimplification of the E value.

Definition.Question: What datasets are commonly used to analyze soil freeze depth in the Yarlung Tsangpo River Basin?
Definition.Answer: Commonly used datasets for analyzing soil freeze depth in the Yarlung Tsangpo River Basin include the UEA-CRU TS 4.03 dataset with a spatial resolution of half-degree from the Climatic Research Unit (CRU) of the University of East Anglia, and a monthly air temperature dataset from 1900–2017 released by the University of Delaware (UDEL). Additionally, daily soil freeze depth is measured by thaw tubes at national meteorological stations, and daily air and ground surface temperatures are collected from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA).

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods for air temperature between the UEA-CRU dataset and the UDEL dataset?
Comparison.Answer: The UEA-CRU dataset uses a spatial resolution of half-degree and collects data from the Climatic Research Unit of the University of East Anglia, whereas the UDEL dataset is extracted from reanalysis products by the University of Delaware, covering monthly air temperatures from 1900 to 2017.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the calibration and evaluation processes for soil freeze depth simulations differ between the use of national meteorological station observations and the Stefan equation?
Comparison.Answer: The calibration and evaluation of soil freeze depth simulations involved using observations from 11 national meteorological stations and 6 nearby stations to calibrate parameters and evaluate simulations by the Stefan equation. This approach contrasts with directly using the Stefan equation with monthly near-surface air temperatures from UEA-CRU and UDEL datasets for simulation.

Interpretation.Question: How might edaphic parameters influence the calculation accuracy of soil freeze depth in data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: The calculation accuracy of soil freeze depth may be impacted by edaphic parameters, as inaccuracies can arise from ignoring or simplifying the treatment of these parameters, potentially leading to deviations in the results.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes deviations in the calculation accuracy of soil freeze depth using the Stefan equation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The calculation accuracy may be deviated by the soil edaphic parameter, and it may also be reduced by the ignorance or simple treatments of the E value.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are long-term observations of permafrost and soil freeze depth inadequate on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations of permafrost and soil freeze depth are inadequate on the Tibetan Plateau, with some exceptions along the Qinghai-Tibet engineering corridor and northeastern Tibetan Plateau, where observations were aimed at monitoring the stability of engineering projects and the response of the eco-environment to climate change.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using the Stefan equation for calculating soil freeze depth on the accuracy of data simulations over long periods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of the Stefan equation may lead to deviations in calculation accuracy, particularly if soil edaphic parameters are not accurately accounted for or if the E value is treated simplistically. This could affect the reliability of long-term simulations of soil freeze depth.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of observational data from meteorological stations influence the accuracy and reliability of soil freeze depth datasets over the UBRB?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating observational data from meteorological stations can help calibrate relevant parameters, improving the accuracy and reliability of soil freeze depth datasets. Observations from 11 national meteorological stations and 6 nearby stations were used to evaluate the simulations and enhance data quality.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the selection of different temperature datasets have on the simulation of frozen ground coverage and soil freeze depth trends in the UBRB?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Different temperature datasets, such as those from UEA-CRU and UDEL, resulted in varied simulations of frozen ground coverage and soil freeze depth trends. The maximum soil freeze depth decreased by different amounts in the simulations with each dataset, highlighting their impact on understanding the warming trend of frozen ground in the UBRB.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use meteorological station observations in calibrating parameters and evaluating simulations of soil freeze depth?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Meteorological station observations are used to calibrate relevant parameters and evaluate simulations in order to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the calculated annual maximum soil freeze depth across the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of using multiple datasets such as the UEA-CRU and UDEL for simulating frozen ground coverage and soil freeze depth?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to simulate the spatial coverage and changes in maximum soil freeze depth, assess the warming trend of frozen ground, and understand differences in results generated using different datasets over the historical period.

The process involves calculating the annual maximum soil freeze depth at all national meteorological stations and each grid point using temperature data from the University of East Anglia Climatic Research Unit (UEA-CRU) and the University of Delaware (UDEL). Observations from meteorological stations are used to calibrate relevant parameters and evaluate the simulations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are meteorological data collected and utilized to support soil freeze depth simulation in the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological data are collected from 11 national meteorological stations in the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin and 6 additional stations nearby. These data include daily soil freeze depth measurements from thaw tubes and daily air and ground surface temperatures from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA). This information is used to calibrate parameters and evaluate soil freeze depth simulations using the Stefan equation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges might arise in the calculation of soil freeze depth due to variations in soil properties, and how can they be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in calculating soil freeze depth can arise due to variations in soil edaphic parameters, which may lead to inaccuracies. These inaccuracies may be exacerbated by the ignorance or simplification of certain values in the calculations. Addressing these challenges may involve improving the accuracy of soil property data and refining calculation methods to account for variability in soil characteristics.

Enablement.Answer: Data collection techniques from the UEA-CRU and UDEL contribute to understanding climate change impacts on soil freezing depth by providing long-term temperature datasets that are used to calculate freezing indices and simulate soil freezing depth. These datasets help analyze spatial and temporal variations of soil freezing depth and assess climate change influences over the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin from 1901 to 2016.
